Award.AwardTitle: Reactivity of Biogenic Volatile Organic Compound Emissions and Their Attribution to Identified Chemical Species
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will investigate the missing reactivity that has been reported in a number of recent studies of biogenic volatile organic compound (BVOC) emissions in the forest atmosphere. It centers on the application of a new approach for the direct determination of the ozone reactivity of BVOC emissions from vegetation. Air drawn from enclosures containing vegetation will be mixed with ozone-enriched air and then passed through a flow tube where the loss of ozone will be measured directly with a differential ozone monitor. Ozone reactivity will be determined for BVOC emissions from a range of vegetation types in the National Center for Atmospheric Research (NCAR) greenhouse, at a local tree nursery in Boulder, CO, at the University of Michigan Biological Station (UMBS), and at the Bio-hydro-atmosphere interactions of Energy, Aerosols, Carbon, H2O, Organics & Nitrogen (BEACHEON) Manitou Forest research site. These vegetation types include the dominant species in U.S. forests. Ozone and OH reactivity experiments conducted in parallel will shed light on how the missing reactivity of these oxidants varies with species, with environmental condition, and relative to each other, thereby providing insight regarding the identities of unknown compounds. The applicability of BVOC + O3 rate constants for estimating the corresponding rates of ozone removal will be evaluated based on kinetic laboratory experiments. Results of the project will help improve photochemical models of radical chemistry in the forest atmosphere. The project will also support continued operation of CU's capillary diffusions system for generating sesquiterpene standards that are used by the PIs' groups as well as other research groups in the community.

The development and evaluation of this new measurement approach has potentially wide-ranging applications for both reevaluating results from past experiments and planning and characterizing BVOC reactivity during future campaigns. This project will contribute to the education of undergraduate students and a postdoctoral researcher. Students from minorities will be recruited from the SOARS and SMART programs to help with the summer field work. The broader public will benefit from presentation of this work to 8th graders at INSTAAR's Annual Open House, through a booth planned at the 2012 Boulder Creek Festival, through a dedicated web portal, and through interactions with the City of Denver "The Mile High Million" program. A better understanding of BVOC chemistry will lead to more effective air pollution mitigation strategies resulting in improved air quality and health.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Ozone in the stratosphere, more than 5 (near the poles) to 10 (around the equator) miles above the earth surface, shields the earth from harmful UV radiations from the sunlight. However, closer to the earth surface in the troposphere, ozone is a potent oxidant and pollutant, causing aging of certain materials such as rubber and textile, impeding photosynthetic process of plants, inflicting leaf tissue damage, and for humans, affecting normal respiratory functions and causing other adverse effects on health. Due to human-caused emissions, the amount of ozone near the earth surface has more than doubled since 1900. To protect the public health, US EPA has specified the limit of maximum amount of ozone allowed to be present in outdoor air.

Forests cover more than 30% of the land area on earth. They play an important role in removing ozone from troposphere. There are different pathways of how ambient ozone is reduced within and directly above forests. In this project, ‘Reactivity of Biogenic Volatile Organic Compound Emissions and Their Attribution to Identified Chemical Species’, we focused on studying how ozone reacts with the organic hydrocarbons released from various types of trees.

To do this, we first built and tested a new type of measurement system, with which we could enclose a small tree branch to capture the natural organic compounds (‘biogenic volatile organic compounds (BVOC)’) released from the tree leaves. The air containing these compounds was then introduced to a reaction chamber where it was mixed with a known amount of ozone. By measuring how much the amount of ozone was reduced in this chamber and how long for it to happen, we could obtain an important quantity termed “ozone reactivity”, describing how fast ozone is removed from air through its chemical reactions with the biogenic hydrocarbons.

In summer 2013 we deployed the instrument in a month-long intensive field campaign, measuring ozone reactivity in the Oakmulgee Division of the Talladega National Forest in Alabama. There we did multiday branch enclosure measurements on sweetgum, white oak, and loblolly pine, all representative tree types of the area. Once we had a tree branch enclosure set up, we kept the instrument on around the clock, obtaining data on the ozone loss rates, at the same time, measuring temperature, light level, humidity, and CO2 of the enclosure – microenvironmental parameters allowing us to have a pulse on the physiological conditions of the tree branch inside. We also collected samples of the air in the enclosures to bring back to our lab for determination of the types and amounts of BVOC that were released by the tree branches.

From the data we collected, we have learned that ozone is removed from the air through its reactions with the organic compounds released by trees, and the removal rates are higher during the day than they are at night. This follows the same pattern of how the trees release BVOC – more during the day when the plants are more active, and less at night. We have also learned that the removal rates have positive correlations with the leaf temperature and the available photosynthetic light – higher temperature and more light lead to faster ozone removal rates. A detailed and quantitative description of these findings will be presented in a peer-reviewed publication of the work.

The broad impacts of this project are reflected in the following areas. As part of the NSF mission, education components were incorporated in this project. Two post-doctoral researchers, one graduate student, and one undergraduate student were involved in instrument preparation, field measurements, sample collection, and post-fieldwork data processing and analysis.

The measurement techniques developed in this project have gained attention and interests from colleagues and scientists working in other research institutions. We are setting up a visitation of researchers from Finland to our lab for them to work with us and developing their own capability of measuring ozone reactivity with the goal to establish long-term observations at a forest research site in Finland. We have completed two trips to Peru, where the PI of this project (Detlev Helmig) transferred branch enclosure and ozone measurement techniques to students and faculty members at the Peru Geophysical Institute, the Pontifical Catholic University of Peru, both in Lima, Peru, and the Universidad Continental at Huancayo, Peru.
